ai-mn70:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kāsīs together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
ai-mn70:2.1_0: “Mendicants, I eat from eating at night.
ai-mn70:2.2_0: Doing so, I find that I’m healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
ai-mn70:2.3_0: You too should abstain from eating at night.
ai-mn70:2.4_0: Doing so, you’ll find that you’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.”
ai-mn70:3.1_0: Then the Buddha, traveling stage by stage in the land of the Kāsīs, arrived at a town of the Kāsīs named Kīṭāgiri,
ai-mn70:4.1_0: At one time Assaji and Punabbasuka were the resident monks at Kīṭāgiri.
ai-mn70:4.2_0: Then several mendicants went up to them and
ai-mn70:4.2_1: and after approaching they said this to the monks Assaji and Punabbasuka:
ai-mn70:4.3_0: “Reverends, the Buddha abstains from eating at night, and so does the mendicant Saṅgha.
ai-mn70:4.4_0: Doing so, they find that they’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
ai-mn70:4.5_0: You too should abstain from eating at night.
ai-mn70:4.6_0: Doing so, you’ll find that you’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.”
ai-mn70:4.7_0: When they said this, the mendicants who followed Assaji and Punabbasuka said to them,
ai-mn70:4.8_0: “Reverends, we eat in the evening, the morning, and at the wrong time of day.
ai-mn70:4.9_0: Doing so, we find that we’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
ai-mn70:4.10_0: Why should we give up what is visible in the present to chase after what takes effect over time?
ai-mn70:4.11_0: We shall eat in the evening, the morning, and at the wrong time of day.”

ai-mn70:6.7_0: The Buddha said to them, “Is it really true, mendicants, that several mendicants went to you and said:

ai-mn70:6.12_0: When they said this, did you really say to them:
ai-mn70:6.13_0: ‘Reverends, we eat in the evening, the morning, and at the wrong time of day.

ai-mn70:6.18_0: “Mendicants, have you ever known me to teach the Dhamma like this: no matter what this individual experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—their unskillful qualities decline and their skillful qualities grow?”
ai-mn70:7.1_0: “Haven’t you known me to teach the Dhamma like this: ‘When someone feels this kind of pleasant feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline. ai-mn70:8.2_0: Now, suppose I hadn’t known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom:
ai-mn70:8.3_0: ‘When someone feels this kind of pleasant feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline.’

ai-mn70:12.1_0: Mendicants, I don’t say that all these mendicants still have work to do with diligence.
ai-mn70:12.2_0: Nor do I say that all these mendicants have no work to do with diligence.
ai-mn70:12.3_0: I say that mendicants don’t have work to do with diligence if they are perfected, with defilements ended, having completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and become rightly freed through enlightenment.
ai-mn70:12.5_0: They’ve done their work with diligence.
ai-mn70:13.1_0: I say that mendicants still have work to do with diligence if they are trainees, who haven’t achieved their heart’s desire, but live aspiring to the supreme sanctuary.
ai-mn70:13.3_0: ‘Hopefully this venerable will frequent appropriate lodgings, associate with good friends, and control their faculties.
ai-mn70:13.4_0: Then they might realize the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life, and live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’
ai-mn70:13.5_0: Seeing this fruit of diligence for those mendicants, I say that they still have work to do with diligence.
ai-mn70:14.1_0: Mendicants, these seven people are found in the world.
ai-mn70:14.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by seven?
ai-mn70:14.3_0: One freed both ways, one freed by wisdom, a personal witness, one attained to view, one freed by faith, a follower of the teachings, and a follower by faith.
ai-mn70:15.1_0: And what person is freed both ways?
ai-mn70:15.2_0: It’s a person who has direct meditative experience of the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements have come to an end.
ai-mn70:15.3_0: This person is called freed both ways.
ai-mn70:15.4_0: And I say that this mendicant has no work to do with diligence.
ai-mn70:15.6_0: They’ve done their work with diligence.
ai-mn70:16.1_0: And what person is freed by wisdom?
ai-mn70:16.2_0: It’s a person who does not have direct meditative experience of the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form. Nevertheless, having seen with wisdom, their defilements have come to an end.
ai-mn70:16.3_0: This person is called freed by wisdom.
ai-mn70:16.4_0: I say that this mendicant has no work to do with diligence.
ai-mn70:16.6_0: They’ve done their work with diligence.
ai-mn70:17.1_0: And what person is a personal witness?
ai-mn70:17.2_0: It’s a person who has direct meditative experience of the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form. And, having seen with wisdom, some of their defilements have come to an end.
ai-mn70:17.3_0: This person is called a personal witness.
ai-mn70:17.4_0: I say that this mendicant still has work to do with diligence.

ai-mn70:18.1_0: And what person is attained to view?
ai-mn70:18.2_0: It’s a person who doesn’t have direct meditative experience of the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form. ai-mn70:18.3_0: This person is called attained to view.

ai-mn70:23.1_0: And how is enlightenment achieved by gradual training, progress, and practice?
ai-mn70:23.2_0: It’s when someone in whom faith has arisen approaches a teacher. They pay homage, lend an ear, hear the teachings, remember the teachings, reflect on their meaning, and accept them after consideration. Then enthusiasm springs up; they make an effort, weigh up, and persevere. Persevering, they directly realize the ultimate truth, and see it with penetrating wisdom.

ai-mn70:27.1_0: For a faithful disciple who is practicing to fathom the Teacher’s instructions, this is in line with the teaching:
ai-mn70:27.2_0: ‘The Buddha is my Teacher, I am his disciple.
ai-mn70:27.3_0: The Buddha knows, I do not know.’
ai-mn70:27.4_0: For a faithful disciple who is practicing to fathom the Teacher’s instructions, the Teacher’s instructions are nourishing and nutritious.
ai-mn70:27.5_0: For a faithful disciple who is practicing to fathom the Teacher’s instructions, this is in line with the teaching:
ai-mn70:27.6_0: ‘Gladly, let my skin, sinews, and bones remain! Let the flesh and blood waste away in my body! I will not stop trying until I have achieved what is possible by human strength, energy, and vigor.’
ai-mn70:27.7_0: A faithful disciple who is practicing to fathom the Teacher’s instructions can expect one of two results:
ai-mn70:27.8_0: enlightenment in the present life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.”
ai-mn70:27.9_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-mn70:27.10_0: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.
